Colonial languages cluster in fewer regions." description: "A scatter plot exploring the geographic spread of African language families. Using the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index to measure speaker concentration, this visualization reveals that indigenous families like Niger-Congo span 40+ countries with evenly distributed speakers, while colonial languages (English, French) cluster in specific regions." date: "2026-01-11" author: - name: "Steven Ponce" url: "https://stevenponce.netlify.app" citation: url: "https://stevenponce.netlify.app/data_visualizations/TidyTuesday/2026/tt_2026_02.html" categories: ["TidyTuesday", "Data Visualization", "R Programming", "2026"] tags: [ "African Languages", "Language Families", "Linguistics", "Geographic Concentration", "Herfindahl-Hirschman Index", "Scatter Plot", "ggplot2", "ggrepel", "Wikipedia Data", "Indigenous Languages", "Colonial Languages" ] image: "thumbnails/tt_2026_02.png" format: html: toc: true toc-depth: 5 code-link: true code-fold: true code-tools: true code-summary: "Show code" self-contained: true theme: light: [flatly, assets/styling/custom_styles.scss] dark: [darkly, assets/styling/custom_styles_dark.scss] editor_options: chunk_output_type: inline execute: freeze: true cache: true error: false message: false warning: false eval: true --- ![Scatter plot showing African language families by geographic concentration versus number of countries. Indigenous families (Niger-Congo, Afroasiatic, Nilo-Saharan) cluster in the upper-left with low concentration and 20-40 countries. Colonial languages (English, French) appear in the lower-right with high concentration in only 3-4 countries.](tt_2026_02.png){#fig-1} ### **Steps to Create this Graphic** #### 1. Load Packages & Setup ::: {.cell} ````{.cell-code} ```{{r}} #| label: load #| warning: false #| message: false #| results: "hide" ## 1. LOAD PACKAGES & SETUP ---- suppressPackageStartupMessages({ if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") pacman::p_load( tidyverse, # Easily Install and Load the 'Tidyverse' ggtext, # Improved Text Rendering Support for 'ggplot2' showtext, # Using Fonts More Easily in R Graphs ggrepel, # Non-overlapping Text Labels janitor, # Simple Tools for Examining and Cleaning Dirty Data scales, # Scale Functions for Visualization glue # Interpreted String Literals ) }) ### |- figure size ---- camcorder::gg_record( dir = here::here("temp_plots"), device = "png", width = 8, height = 6, units = "in", dpi = 320 ) # Source utility functions suppressMessages(source(here::here("R/utils/fonts.R"))) source(here::here("R/utils/social_icons.R")) source(here::here("R/utils/image_utils.R")) source(here::here("R/themes/base_theme.R")) ``` ```` ::: #### 2. Read in the Data ::: {.cell} ````{.cell-code} ```{{r}} #| label: read #| include: true #| eval: true #| warning: false tt <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2026, week = 02) africa_raw <- tt$africa |> clean_names() tidytuesdayR::readme(tt) rm(tt) ``` ```` ::: #### 3. Examine the Data ::: {.cell} ````{.cell-code} ```{{r}} #| label: examine #| include: true #| eval: true #| results: 'hide' #| warning: false glimpse(africa_raw) ``` ```` ::: #### 4. Tidy Data ::: {.cell} ````{.cell-code} ```{{r}} #| label: tidy-fixed #| warning: false #' Note: #' HHI (Herfindahl-Hirschman Index) measures market concentration - originally used #' in economics to see if one company dominates a market. We're adapting it to see #' if one country dominates a language family's speaker base. #' ### |- calculate HHI concentration + country coverage ---- family_summary <- africa_raw |> filter(!is.na(native_speakers), native_speakers > 0) |> group_by(family, country) |> summarise( speakers = sum(native_speakers), .groups = "drop" ) |> group_by(family) |> mutate( total = sum(speakers), share = speakers / total ) |> summarise( hhi_concentration = sum(share^2), n_countries = n_distinct(country), .groups = "drop" ) |> filter(n_countries > 1) |> group_by(family) |> slice_max(n_countries, n = 1) |> ungroup() |> mutate( family_group = if_else(family %in% c("English", "French"), "Colonial", "Indigenous") ) ### |- labels for key points ---- label_df <- family_summary |> filter( str_detect(family, regex("^English$|^French$|Niger|Afroasiatic|Nilo", ignore_case = TRUE)) ) ``` ```` ::: #### 5. Visualization Parameters ::: {.cell} ````{.cell-code} ```{{r}} #| label: params #| include: true #| warning: false ### |- plot aesthetics ---- colors <- get_theme_colors( palette = c( "Colonial" = "#E76F51", "Indigenous" = "gray40" ) ) ### |- titles and caption ---- title_text <- str_glue("Africa's Indigenous Language Families Span the Continent") subtitle_text <- str_glue( "Niger-Congo, Afroasiatic, and Nilo-Saharan are spoken natively across 20â€“40 countries
with speakers evenly distributed. ", "Colonial languages cluster in fewer regions.", ) caption_text <- create_social_caption( tt_year = 2026, tt_week = 02, source_text = "Wikipedia 'Languages of Africa' | Concentration = Herfindahl-Hirschman Index" ) ### |- fonts ---- setup_fonts() fonts <- get_font_families() ### |- plot theme ---- # Start with base theme base_theme <- create_base_theme(colors) # Add weekly-specific theme elements weekly_theme <- extend_weekly_theme( base_theme, theme( # Text styling plot.title = element_text( face = "bold", family = fonts$title, size = rel(1.4), color = colors$title, margin = margin(b = 10), hjust = 0 ), plot.subtitle = element_markdown( face = "italic", family = fonts$subtitle, lineheight = 1.2, color = colors$subtitle, size = rel(0.9), margin = margin(b = 20), hjust = 0 ), # Grid panel.grid.minor = element_blank(), panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray90", linewidth = 0.25), # Axes axis.title.x = element_text(size = 9.5, color = "gray30", margin = margin(t = 8)), axis.title.y = element_text(size = 9.5, color = "gray30", margin = margin(r = 8)), # axis.title = element_text(size = rel(0.8), color = "gray30"), axis.text = element_text(color = "gray30"), axis.text.y = element_text(size = rel(0.85)), axis.ticks = element_blank(), # Facets strip.background = element_rect(fill = "gray95", color = NA), strip.text = element_text( face = "bold", color = "gray20", size = rel(0.9), margin = margin(t = 6, b = 4) ), panel.spacing = unit(1.5, "lines"), # Legend elements legend.position = "plot", legend.title = element_text( family = fonts$subtitle, color = colors$text, size = rel(0.8), face = "bold" ), legend.text = element_text( family = fonts$tsubtitle, color = colors$text, size = rel(0.7) ), legend.margin = margin(t = 15), # Plot margin plot.margin = margin(20, 20, 20, 20), ) ) # Set theme theme_set(weekly_theme) ``` ```` ::: #### 6. Plot ::: {.cell} ````{.cell-code} ```{{r}} #| label: plot #| warning: false ### |- Plot ---- p <- ggplot(family_summary, aes(x = hhi_concentration, y = n_countries)) + # Geoms geom_point( aes(color = family_group), size = 3, alpha = 0.85 ) + geom_text_repel( data = label_df, aes(label = family, color = family_group), size = 3.0, fontface = "bold", box.padding = 0.4, point.padding = 0.3, segment.color = "gray70", segment.size = 0.3, max.overlaps = Inf, seed = 123 ) + # Scales scale_color_manual( values = colors$palette, guide = "none" ) + scale_x_continuous( limits = c(0, 1.1), breaks = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1) ) + scale_y_continuous( breaks = seq(0, 45, by = 10) ) + # Labs labs( title = title_text, subtitle = subtitle_text, caption = caption_text, x = "Speaker Concentration\n(0 = evenly spread across countries, 1 = single country dominates)", y = "Number of Countries" ) + # Theme theme( axis.title.y = element_text( angle = 0, # Makes it horizontal vjust = 1.02, # Pushes it to the top of the axis hjust = 0.5, margin = margin(r = -50) # Adjusts distance from the axis ), plot.title = element_markdown( size = rel(1.4), family = fonts$title, face = "bold", color = colors$title, lineheight = 1.15, margin = margin(t = 0, b = 5) ), plot.subtitle = element_markdown( size = rel(0.8), family = fonts$subtitle, color = alpha(colors$subtitle, 0.88), lineheight = 1.5, margin = margin(t = 5, b = 20) ), plot.caption = element_markdown( size = rel(0.5), family = fonts$subtitle, color = colors$caption, hjust = 0, lineheight = 1.4, margin = margin(t = 20, b = 5) ) ) ``` ```` ::: #### 7. Save ::: {.cell} ````{.cell-code} ```{{r}} #| label: save #| warning: false ### |- plot image ---- save_plot( plot = p, type = "tidytuesday", year = 2026, week = 02, width = 8, height = 6, ) ``` ```` ::: #### 8.
